Beautiful song. And very insightful, At first, one would answer the question it poses with an unequivocal "yes." The concept of eternal life is common o the Three Great Monotheistic Faiths, But think about it-- The first few hundred years would be great. You would have travelled everywhere, gotten many advanced degrees if you were so inclined, met thousands of interesting people, made love to thousands more. You would have indulged your senses in every way imaginable. After a thousand years you would have met everyone you'd have wanted to meet, gone everywhere you wanted to go. The mere presence of your loved ones whom you once held so dear would now be a major irritant. you'd have done pretty much everything you'd have wanted to do, so what's left? You could do them again, but they would have lost much of their appeal after you've done them already, let alone thousands of times. This is eternity after all. You'd be bored shitless. Life is precious because it limited. If it were to last forever it would eventually lose all of it's meaning.                                      .

I saw Queen twice in my late teens, right after the release of News of the World. It was pretty much decided that we were witnessing one of the greatest bands in the history of Rock music and music in general. Considering the emphasis on slick guitar solos during that time and Brian May being principally (by his own admission) a rhythm guitarist, it was amazing how much sophisticated sound they generated from three instruments and Freddie occasionally playing piano on some songs. In addition to Freddie's otherwordly vocals they were phenomenal songwriters as well. They remain the tightest band I ever saw on the stage. For me, and maybe others who believe in the same way, Who Wants to Live Forever is their finest song. It has become the song I think of when Queen comes to mind, even over Bohemian Rhapsody. We'll never see this quality of talent assembled in one band ever again. Simply amazing.
